headline: Authentic German Potato Salad
description: Bacon gives this warm German potato salad recipe a boost of flavor. Vinegar and sugar in the dressing are the perfect combination of salty and sweet.

video.description: See how to make traditional vinegar-based potato salad with bacon!
video.name: Authentic German Potato Salad

name: Authentic German Potato Salad
recipeIngredient: 1.5 tablespoons white sugar, or more to taste

recipeInstructions.text: Place potatoes in a large pot and add water to cover by at least 1 to 2 inches; bring to a boil. Cook until potatoes are easily pierced with a fork, about 10 minutes. Drain, and set aside to cool.

While the potatoes are cooking, place bacon in a large, deep skillet over medium-high heat. Fry until browned and crisp, 10 to 12 minutes, turning as needed. Transfer bacon to a paper towel-lined plate and crumble when cool enough to handle. Leave bacon grease in the skillet.
Cook onion in the bacon grease over medium heat until browned, 6 to 8 minutes. Add vinegar, sugar, water, salt, and pepper to the pan and bring to a boil.
Once boiling, add potatoes, and 1/2 of the crumbled bacon. Cook until heated through, 3 to 4 minutes.
Transfer warm potato salad to a serving dish and sprinkle remaining bacon over top. Garnish with parsley. Serve immediately.

review.reviewBody: Made it exactly as written and it was perfect!
We made this recipe with slightly less than a tablespoon of sugar. Everyone enjoyed it and no one complained about not enough sugar.
Very tasty! For convenience I used a generous amount of real crumbled bacon from Costco and dried parsley. The 1 1/2 tbsp of sugar was perfect.

I love this recipe. So easy to make and the family (who gets sick of mummy's love of potatoes) love it too! Nice combo of sweet, salty and tangy. I don't peel my potatoes, I also add a little dried dill to serve.
Just like my German Grandmother used to make! Followed the recipe exactly. I might add a little more vinegar next time.
I love this recipe and always double the delicious dressing. It is always a hit!
I add some celery to it when I cook the onions. It's my "Go To" side with Prime Rib. I even impressed a cooking instructor with this one. Thank You for the recipe.

First I used white vinegar as the written recipe states however video says white wine vinegar...Which is it? This was delicious and will continue to use this recipe but curious about the white wine taste, if there is a difference
I substituted sugar for Spenda and used Jalape√±o bacon which gave it a nice spicy and sweet kick!
Just did a random search online for German Potato Salad. The family loved it!!!

I love this recipe even if using canned sliced potatoes to speed up the process, but thought that I would mention that the recipe doesn't mention when to add the parsley. I just assumed as garnish. Serving with a pork loin with apples and onions tonight! üòÅ
I omitted the sugar from this recipe. And then followed the rest of it exactly. It was absolutely delicious.

My wife loves potatoes. This is her favorite potato dish. I smoked a chuck roast like a brisket. This potato salad pairs excellent with roast prepared that way! Easy to prepare will I let the meat rest, so that every dish was hot/warm.
So good. Will make again.
This tasted just like my Austrian Grandma's so I give it a 5 stars!
Awesome recipe, has all the information grandma used to use. Thank u for sharing!
Love it!

I didn't make it yet, but my sister-in-law did, and it was amazing! My mother is from Germany, and I am a German potato snob, and so is my man. We both really enjoyed this version, and I will be making it myself, very soon! Thank you for the recipe!!
Seems like the liquid should have been thickened a bit. Awful watery in bottom of dish.

I LOVE this recipe!!! I made one minor simplifying change - used red skin potatoes (on the smaller size), boiled whole, cooled then removed most but not all of the skin (it just falls off after cooked and cooled), then sliced potatoes and continued with recipe as written. It was really good!
don't be afraid to use the vinegar! balance it with sugar. it is really really good!!
My mother made this when I was growing up, I continue to make it exactly how you say, my grandparents came from Germany. This her mother made. Love it and so do my friends!,
Husband loved it!
Love this potato salad and everyone that ate it did. I have made it about ten times and plan to continue, no other recipe needed.
Simply delicious!! I didn't change anything, well, I did leave a little skin on the red potatoes... still was awesome!
It was so good .I'm going to keep this recipe.My husband really likes this
I was using up odds and ends and had to use some red onion and green onion, but it tasted great and was easy to make.
Next time I would add much less sugar, and salt. Bacon created a lot of grease, I used maybe 2 TBSP.
I was looking for a recipe and this is the first one I saw and it is reminiscent of my German relatives Bavarian hot potato salad can't wait to make this Thank you very much for this posting!

My husband hates mayonnaise so I wanted to find a potato salad that does not use it. I changed the recipe up a bit for my July 4th family dinner. I used 1 lb of bacon and about 8 large red potatoes. I used green onion instead of red onion and I forgot to put sugar in it. I did however only used 1/4 cup of vinegar and I used Goya perfect seasoning instead of salt. I left the potato on the heat until it absorbed all of the sauce. It came out so good. My family loved the potato salad, even my brother in law who doesn‚Äôt like anything.
Sliced the potatoes rather than dicing, but otherwise followed the recipe. Turned out great!
This is the BEST recipe for German Potato Salad I have found. It's exactly like my Oma & Mama made when I was growing up. Now I can make it for my daughter & friends

Well, I did make it, however I did not notice the very last two words in the directions until too late. Serve Warm. I had intended to have this later in the day for dinner with some pork chops and asparagus. Didn't know it was to be served hot. My bad I guess. I am sure it will be alright later, just maybe not quite as intended. We did taste it and it is really good. Hope it holds up till dinner!

Recipe very good easy to follow good flavoring but suggested you might wanna taste test before serving need it just a little bit touch of love what I mean by that is a little bit more salt pepper Sugar to sweetened up in a tad more vinegar I put apple cider vinegar Give it more about German Style potato Style taste Thank you yours truly Sgt miller/aka Mr. chef on Instagram
I strictly followed the recipe. This is really good. I want more tanginess so 4 stars.

While there are many fine variations of this, I disagree with the methods. Potato salads (German or the mayo kind) are ALWAYS better if the red potatoes are boiled whole, THEN peeled and sliced or chunked. None of the potato flavor gets washed away. Takes a little longer, but the results are sooo much better.
Way too much sugar, not enough vinegar. Had a weird muted sweet taste. Need to remove some bacon grease I‚Äôd say about half to cook the onions in. Will have to try a different recipe.
Delicious! I did add a little bit more vinegar to my taste.
10 min to cook the potatoes to tender huh...lol idiot

It was ok. After reading the reviews I did use to tablespoons of sugar instead of three. I could taste all the flavors but the just didn't meld together very well. Let me ask this: I see in the video she used long red potatoes. The only red potatoes we have here are small round ones. I used russet potatoes. Would that make a difference?
Absolutely delicious. Some German potato salad recipes that I have tried don't have enough tang, but this one has that tangy, bacon flavor I love!

Excellent Amish German Potato salad my mom use to make from the hills of Ohio~2 things, you want the sauce to shine, to glisten over the potato‚Äôs, so I add a tsp. of corn starch to thicken the sauce a little. I do not use parsley. I use ‚ÄúCELERY SEED‚Äù( use to your own desire). Gives that (pickled) taste to the dish.

TL;DR: all the right ingredients, but taste as you go and adjust amounts to your preference. This has all the right ingredients but I found the proportions off for my tastes. I started to add the sugar and stopped at two because it already appeared to be too much. I‚Äôm glad I didn‚Äôt add the third because it would have been insanely sweet. I ended up adding more vinegar and even some mustard to cut the sweetness. I also cooked 10 pieces of bacon to have it ready for other things and ended up just adding all of it; but that‚Äôs definitely a matter of personal preference.
Authentic or not, this is delicious and simple to make. I always have it at my Oktoberfest tailgate.
Very good. I did increase the sauce by half after reading other reviews. I could have doubled it. I also didn‚Äôt peel the potatoes. Turned out really good!

My husband made this and he is a BY THE BOOK sort of guy. He did it *exactly* as written. I bought the ingredients, so he used red potatoes, cider vinegar, and flat parsley. These are my issues with this recipe: Step 3 is a hot mess (pun intended). It should be 3 separate steps: 3) making the sauce, 4) adding the potatoes, and 5) adding the parsley right before serving. There is also no need to "heat through" any of it after boiling, it should only be tossed together. The result of his endeavors was a very vinegary, lumpy, mashed potato mix with brown, wilted weed-looking things throughout. Heating parsley in an acid is going to do nothing good for its appearance. I pulled ALL the parsley out, which was a big hassle. I found it to be a little sweet, but the "salad" was a hit at the BBQ we went to, so I'm giving it 3 stars.
Good! Add chives, don't mince the potatoes, leave enough size to bite.
Delicious! I used red potatoes, apple cider vinegar and brown sugar. So good.

I used Yellow Dutch Baby potatoes which I left unpeeled and halved the larger ones. I then cooked them the Instant Pot for 2 minutes and let the pressure naturally release for 5 minutes. I also used red wine vinegar instead of white vinegar and doubled the amount of bacon.

I made this for our Oktoberfest party and it was a huge hit! Everyone raves about how good it was. The tiny bit of leftovers disappeared the next day. 

I quadrupled the recipe. I quartered small red potatoes and cooked them in the instant pot for 4 minutes. Added them into the recipe as written. I was a little worried about how runny it was at first, but scooped into a large ceramic bowl, covered and kept in a warm oven for several hours before serving. It was perfect!
A little less sugar. Added a little fresh dill, extra slice of bacon to crumble, stone ground mustard. Also half vinegar half pickle juice
I love this simple recipe. I reduced the sugar and added a sprinkle more vinegar for personal taste.
A new addition to my potato lineup. I forgot to top it off with the extra bacon. Still yummy and brought me back to my childhood potato salads!
Made this today for the second time for 20 people so I multiplied it by 4. It came out great was a big hit!!! This is my go to recipe for German potato salad
This was so good and easy! My husband doesn‚Äôt normally like German potato salad but this one had him coming back for seconds. Thanks for the recipe!
It‚Äôs very good, simple, and tasty, but just a tiny bit too sweet for me. Next time I make it I‚Äôm going to halve the sugar.

I absolutely loved it!! My husband thought I needed to add less sugar, but I think that was due to the fact I used maple brown sugar bacon. My husband loved it as well and said that it tasted quite similar to his mother's. It was my first go at it especially being German and trying to replicate my husband's favorite side dish. It was fantastic!!!

I made it according to recipe except I didn‚Äôt use as much sugar and I tripled everything because, I used 5lb‚Äôs of red potatoes and then I used 1 1/2 of fresh string beans that I boiled in the left over chicken broth that I boiled the potatoes in. It came out Delicious!!!
This is a very easy recipe and takes no time at all. Definitely a keeper!
Excellent easy recipe! I always boil my potatoes with peelings and remove while quite warm. They come right off! Keeps cold and warm salads from getting mucky. Lefse turns out better that way too
made this. it is more sweet and sour than what we get at authentic german restaurants but it is good.

My grandfather was German Swiss, and I really wanted a recipe which was similar to his. This one came closest without calling for an inordinately huge amount of sugar. I made a couple of alterations so that it was more to my particular liking. I only put in one tablespoon of sugar (just enough to offset the bitterness of the vinegar, like what is done to tomato sauce, not to make the sauce sweet) and increased the amount of vinegar to four tablespoons. Plus, I added a tablespoon of flour to thicken the sauce. Now, I think of Granddaddy when I take a bite. Delicious!
Couldn't find my old recipe but knew this was really close. Add a couple of tablespoons of flour to the sauteed onions to make a roux before adding vinegar mixture. Perfect!
I put a smidgeon of dill in as suggested‚Ä¶it was a hidden surprise flavor!
We had it this weekend with smoked fish and it was really good. I am definitely saving to try this again.

I‚Äôve been meaning to make a German potato salad ever since we returned from our vacation in Germany. We stayed in Vilseck, in northern Bavaria. We had authentic German potato salad, and this recipe is delicious and very close to what we ate.

I‚Äôm German, but not a German cook. My husband seemed to like it. Needed more of something not sure what. I like when the relatives make it, Yum, but this was ok. I never seem to get seasoning right. I do like the cucumbers in it .
Super easy! I added the whole package of bacon I mean really who doesn't love bacon!

This recipe is perfect. The only change I made was I added extra vinegar and reduced the sugar to 1 tablespoon. I also topped it with chopped green onion and more chopped parsley. My husband loved it.

I made this tonight and it was outstanding! Didn't have any white wine vinegar so I substituted plain white vinegar and a quarter cup of pilot grigio. Dicing the potatoes before cooking cut down on cooking time! This recipe is a keeper! Thanks to your mom and to you for sharing it!
Finally I found a recipe like mom's!
Delicious! Don‚Äôt change a thing!

I love this recipe, I've made it several times now. The only thing I do different is add to many potatoes so I have to add more 
ingredients but that's my fault, this is delicious!
My friend from Germany gave me this recipe many, many years ago. Only difference is she sliced the potatoes into think circles instead of cubes. Wonderful recipe and so easy.

Easy peasy. That's nice. I used organic, unfiltered, cider vinegar and decreased the sugar to 2T, because I am constitutionally unable to follow a recipe to the letter. Will let you know how it is when it cools off. :)
This recipe was great. I would add some mustard to the dressing to give it a more classic flavor, but other than that, it was super good and easy to make.
This recipe tasted just like my Oma's recipe. I like it better than most potato salads I had while living in Germany.
Absolutely love this. Adjusted up to family size of 18 servings using a 5 lb bag of potatoes. Turned out great. Will make again.
I took out most of the bacon fat before adding the onions.
super easy to make. i loved it. but i think next time i will do double the vinegar and half the sugar. i love a vinegar flavoring

Very basic and simple to make. I've always left the peels on my potatoes and just slice them.

I doubled the recipe except for the sugar and onion. 

I grew up with great aunts from Germany and this is a must for our Christmas dinner and slow roasted pork.

This recipe is about as authentic as it gets. My family is German and I have been eating German potato salad since my youth. This is up there with some of the best I‚Äôve had. Do yourself a favor and make it!
Made this recipe twice now & didn‚Äôt change a single ingredient- only change was - I doubled the amount to have leftovers.

Our family includes picky eaters. This was an absolute hit with everyone!! The use of the bacon fat to saut√© the onions makes this so flavorful! I agree with others that reducing the sugar by half is advisable. Definitely going into the rotation :-) And whenever potlucks become the norm, I‚Äôm volunteering to make this.

Made this for a mini Oktoberfest at my house and everyone loved it. Especially my friend from Germany who hates mayo, pickles, and eggs haha. 

I used red potatoes, half white vinegar and half apple cider vinegar, doubled the bacon and only used 1/3 of the sugar in the original recipe. I also made a little extra of the liquid because I like things sauces. Oh and I also cooked the bacon in the oven and then just poured the grease into a saucepan.
Easy to make and everyone loved it!
I followed directions but added more bacon to the salad- great. Everyone liked it at our German October fest.
it was devoured by everyone!
We have an annual Oktoberfest party with a big crowd. I make this dish every year, and everyone raves about it! It‚Äôs perfect the way that it is!
amazing! So easy to make. Tasted so good. Making it again.

Loved it! I halved the amount of sugar and doubled the sauce. I boiled the potatoes in their skins and then ran them under cold water before peeling. I coarsely cut them in a baking dish and then poured the sauce over the potatoes. Delicious!!!
So good! I only used 1 tbs sugar and it was perfect for our taste. First time making german potato salad from scratch and not from the can.

I liked it! Served it at a party and everyone liked it. Personally it was bit sweet so I'll curb the sugar a little next time. I was going to put celery seed like some reviewers mentioned but I forgot, so I made it as the recipe stated.
I love love love this recipe. I doubled the recipe hoping for left overs, but no luck. It was all gone!

I don‚Äôt eat meat but my husband does. I grew up eating German potato salad and sometimes I do miss it! Although I could not taste what I had prepared, the reactions of my friends said it all! I should have made more!! Didn‚Äôt expect 2nd helpings all around!!
This is simply the best German Potato Salad I have ever had. I substituted apple cider vinegar as I didn't have white vinegar at the time. Absolutely delicious.

Made it for 10 servings for a bible study. Cut sugar in half. fried 10 Chopped up slices bacon & only used about 3 tbs of bacon grease to saut√© onions (rest went into grease jar!) Used Braggs apple cider vinegar & instead of parsley used fresh dill & about 1/2 tsp of celery seed. Was a huge success. Brought home a empty bowl!!!! I am estimating amounts so it‚Äôs up 2 your preference. I prefer a more vinegar taste than sweet especially if warm. So if you want more sweet add more sugar to your taste etc.
My mom always made delicious German Potato Salad and I didn't have her recipe and this one was spot on, tasted just like hers. Very Authentic! Thank you for sharing! :)
I added celery and green apple to onion and bacon drippings. Healthy and delicious.
